Vector Spaces

Vector Space Structure

A vector space over a field is a set of elements called vectors equipped with an addition and a scalar multiplication:

  • A field of scalars

  • A set of vectors

    • Commutativity
    • Associativity
    • Unique additive identity
    • Unique additive inverse
    • The vector space is closed under addition

    • Associativity over scalars
    • Unique multiplicative identity
    • Distributivity over vectors
    • Distributivity over scalars
    • The vector space is closed under scalar multiplication

Linear Independence

A set of vectors in a vector space is said to be linearly independent if

Otherwise, the set is said to be linearly dependent.

Propositions and Corollaries
  1. Any set which contains a linearly dependent set is linearly dependent.
  2. Any subset of a linearly independent set is linearly independent.
  3. Any set containing the zero vector is linearly dependent.
  4. A set is linearly independent if and only if each finite subset of is linearly independent.
  5. Removing the redundant vector from a set does not change its span.

 

Bases

Let be a vector space. A basis for is a linearly independent spanning set for . If is a basis of , then every vector can be written as a unique linear combination of vectors in .

Finding a Basis for

Let be a finite-dimensional vector space. To find a basis for :

  1. Find a general form for vectors .
  2. Write the general form of as a linear combination of vectors in .
  3. Check if is linearly independent. If so then it is a basis. Otherwise, find a vector which can be written as a linear combination of other vectors in and remove it from the set.
  4. Repeat this process until is linearly independent.

System of Linear Equations

System of Linear Equations

A set of linear equations in the same variables is called a system of linear equations in variables. Two systems are equivalent if each equation in each system is a linear combination of the equations in the other system.

 

Solution to the System of Linear Equations

A vector is called a solution if all equations are satisfied when we set for . The set of all solutions of a system of linear equations is called the solution set of the system. Equivalent systems have the same solutions. If a system of linear equations has at least one solution, then it is said to be consistent. Otherwise, it is said to be inconsistent.

General Solution

If the system of linear equations has two distinct solutions and , then the solution set is given by .

 

Elementary Row Operations

Applying any of these three elementary row operations to a matrix is called row reducing the matrix:

  1. Multiplying a row by a non-zero scalar.
  2. Adding a multiple of one row to another.
  3. Swapping two rows.
Row Equivalence

Two matrices and are said to be row equivalent if there exists a (finite) sequence of elementary row operations that transform into . We write . Row equivalence is an equivalence relation (reflexive, symmetric, transitive). If , then the homogeneous systems and have the same solutions.

 

Row Reduced Echelon Form

  3. Each column with a leading one has all other entries zero.

Very Important Remark on RREF

Consider the system with being RREF. Let rows be the non-zero rows of and suppose that the leading non-zero entry of row occurs in column . The system then consists of non-trivial equations (every other equation is of the form ). The unknown will occur (with a non-zero coefficient) only in the th equation:

  1. The th column of keeps record of the coefficients for variable ; the th entry (row) of the column vector represents the coefficient of in th equation.
  2. By construction, the leading one of th row occurs in th column, which is saying that in th equation has coefficient .
  3. By definition of RREF, since contains a leading one, every other entry of that column must be zero. Then by (1) and (2), has a coefficient of zero in every other equations except row .
  4. Hence, the unknown will occur with a non-zero coefficient only in the th equation.

Homogeneous Systems

A system of linear equations is said to be a homogeneous system if the right-hand side only contains zeros.

Solution Space

The solution set of a homogeneous system is a vector space. Thus it is also called the solution space of the system.

Inhomogeneous Systems

While the homogeneous system always has a trivial solution, the inhomogeneous system doesn't always have one, i.e. it can be inconsistent.

Eigenvalue and Eigenvectors

Let . If there exists such that , then is called an eigenvalue of and is called an eigenvector of corresponding to . The pair is called an eigenpair.

Motivation

During a linear transformation, most vectors are going to get knocked off their span, but some special vectors remain on their span (line), meaning that the effect that the matrix has on such a vector is just to stretch or squish it like a scalar. These special vectors are called eigenvectors and the factor by which it is stretched or squished during the transformation is called the eigenvalue. Thus finding the eigenvector and eigenvalues of comes down to finding the values of and that makes the expression , where is the matrix representation of some linear transformation .

To solve this equation, we observe

In other words, we now have a new matrix , which has the same entries as except on the diagonal entries where is replaced by . Since this matrix/linear transformation casts to the zero vector, and we are solving for the kernel of this matrix/linear transformation. It is important to remember that to qualify as an eigenvector, , i.e. the set of all eigenvectors associated with an eigenvalue is the null space of excluding the zero vector. Geometrically speaking, since the only way for a non-zero vector to get mapped to a zero vector is when the space is squished into a lower dimension, we have .

  1. A transformation doesn't have to have eigenvectors, e.g. rotation: .
  2. A transformation can have limited eigenvectors, e.g. shear: .
  3. One eigenvalue can be paired up with multiple vectors, e.g. s.t. every vector is stretched by a factor of .

Diagonalization

Let . is diagonalizable if is similar to a diagonal matrix . If , then we say that diagonalizes .

Characterization
  1. An matrix over is diagonalizable if and only if the sum of the dimensions of its eigenspaces is equal to , which is the case if and only there exists a basis of consisting of eigenvectors of . if such a basis has been found, one can form the matrix having these basis vectors as columns, and will be a diagonal matrix. The diagonal entries of this matrix are the eigenvalues of .
  2. A linear map is diagonalizable if and only if the sum of the dimensions of its eigenspaces is equal to , which is the case if and only if there exists a basis of consisting of eigenvectors of . With respect to such a basis, will be represented by a diagonal matrix. The diagonal entries of this matrix are the eigenvalues of .
  3. An matrix is diagonalizable over if its has distinct eigenvalues in , i.e. if its characteristic polynomial has distinct roots in . Note that the converse may be false.
  4. A linear map with is diagonalizable if it has distinct eigenvalues, i.e. if its characteristic polynomial has distinct roots in .
  5. If is diagonalizable, then so is any power of it. Conversely, if is invertible, is algebraically closed and is diagonalizable for some that is not an integer multiple of the characteristic of , then is diagonalizable.

An matrix is diagonalizable if and only if there exists a basis for of eigenvectors of .

Algorithm for Diagonalizing a Matrix

To diagonalize or show is not diagonalizable:

  2. Let denote the -roots of (repeated according to multiplicity). If any of the eigenvalues are not real, is not diagonalizable.
